reviewText:
The Talos Principle is a first person puzzle game spiced up with some philosophy.

The Talos Principle is one of the most impressive games I have ever played. For starters, the game is incredibly user friendly with HUGE options menu with everything you could want from video game options menu. The music is also awe inspiring and the graphics are absolutelly beautiful, not just for a puzzle game.

The puzzles have a good difficulty curve, but there were few instances where I had to do something that I didn't know I could do in game to complete the puzzle.

The story is instantly interesting, with good writing and voice acting.

The game is around 20 hours long for first time players, which is good amount of content, but I got the feeling that its over staying its welcome by few hours.

If you are fan of Portal/Portal 2 or good games in general, The Talos Principle is for you! I absolutely recommend The Talos Principle.


You don't need a degree in philosophy to understand this game.

reviewText:
One of the most beautiful, witty and at the same time philosophical puzzle games I've ever played. It's brilliantly balanced, the narrator hits home, the different worlds are superbly designed and this is probably one of the best games I've ever played.

If you liked Portal and are even in the slightest philosophically inclined, you'll love this. If you don't even know what philosophy is, you'll be weirded out and will still like the puzzles.

If you don't like puzzles and buy this for robots, I can't help you.

reviewText:
The Talos Principle is beautiful. It’s beautiful on more than one way.

Naturally the setting - the forest island especially is a very pleasant and fitting surrounding. There is very little metal around; it feels very peaceful and just nice to look at. Sets it apparat from most games.

It has nice sound - the music, its soft, it doesnt bother your, it sounds like thinking music, which it should be. Awesome.

It’s got a confusing and intellectually stimulating plot. Its a claver game. If you let it, it will make you think. Laugh. Think some more.

The puzzles are good. They are. There are lots of them, most of them are not very hard, but there are a lot of them and you will spend quite some time figuring out the trickier ones. It’s good. The way it should be.

The gameplay is solid. Everything works. There is no trickery involved. If you can’t get somewhere you are not supposed to do. You don’t have to perform some weird messed up pathing exercises walking on transparent walls.

It’s a really proper puzzle game. I mean there are rooms with puzzles that are in rooms with puzzles that are in a room with puzzles and to get to the rooms you have to solve puzzles.

If you don't like puzzles, you'll really hate it.

9/10
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: After a stunning year of game releases in 2013, I was disappointed with the few notable releases in 2014.  Well, just in time to save it came The Talos Principle.  This is the best game I've played in a long while.  The game mechanics are very well polished, the graphics are beautiful, and the puzzles hit the perfect balance of challenging but doable (and there are over a hundred of them!).  The best part, though, is the story.  I didn't expect to get clobbered with a powerful lesson in philosophy while gaming.  Once I started, I was obsessed with it and hardly played anything else until I completed it.  The ending was not only satisfying, it kind of blew me away.\n\nIt took me 32 hours to complete the game, and I expect to spend several more finding all the secrets, so it's well worth paying full price.  I can't recommend this game enough!  This is the best game of 2014.

reviewText:
The Talos Principle is a good game for people who were aching for a real puzzle challenge. With over 120 varied puzzles this game delivers for its hefty price of 45 euros. A little warning though, dedication is required.  Because this game uses only a limited set of elements to create its challenges, puzzles may start to look a lot alike before you're even half way. It  actually caused me to burn out on the game at first.  There were two things that kept me playing.

First, experimenting, exploration and trying to break the physics of the game is greatly rewarded. I have a knack for doing silly stuff in games when i'm burned out on the main and side quests. running, jumping and fooling around. Here I started to mess with the jump platforms. Could I jump over the walls of the puzzle area? Could I take stuff from the area with me? What would could I do with that? Surprisingly this  goofing  payed off. This game rewarded my  'efforts' by reaching extra sigils and easter eggs. It's great fun and adds to being really engaged in the story, because the exploration and easter eggs  give it more depth.

The story, and the way you experience it, was the next thing to keep my attention. I really like games that dare to pose questions to me as a player. Questions like for example: What makes someone human? or what is a soul? or what is  time? It makes the game 'stick' for me, because  thinking about it really really engages me more in the protagonist of the game. Here this works perfectly. You awake as the 'program/soul' of a clueless robot trying to find its way and purpose.  Robots are build for a task, right? But what is that task in this world without humans? What happened here anyway?
The experience of the game adds to the story. The tale of finding your purpose is one of many choices you have to make in 'life' and the feeling that comes with it. A feeling of never knowing you chose right. The Elohim voiceover (brilliantly done), messages and q&a's though the computer terminals and QR-codes were constantly trying to push me around. And when even the puzzles are trying to trick you, you know something is not right. I was always suspicious of who I could trust and what the results would be. Through this concept I really was engaged in the journey of the robot and it's search.

Are you looking for a game that puzzles you in more ways than one? This is it.

reviewText:
What if... God was real?

But instead of wanting you to be nice to other people, there were no other people and instead He wanted you to mess with Tetris™ pieces in order to live forever?

That is the terrifying premise of The Talos Project. It is the best game of 2014, or at least this December.
As shown in the promo images, this game also features two of my favorite things:

• Being a robot
• Petting a cat!!!

I've always wanted to be a robot, so it's pretty neat that I can do that in the game. No cats though! (Update: I found a cat, but I couldn't pet it :(((  )

It reminds me a little of the Mac game Marathon because of all the computer terminals. But in that game, you couldn't see if your hand were human hands, so if you were a robot or a cyborg was a mystery. The Talos Principal is better, because you can tell you are a robot right away, it's like the first thing that happens. Also, in the game you can type much faster and more accurately than I can in real life. I guess that's a third awesome feature!

• Typing quickly and accurately

I haven't finished yet, but if you like platform puzzles, reading about the nature of existence (Actual Kant excerpts in game, for real), and thinking about how sad the apocolypse is going to be, this is the game for you.

I give The Tavros Principle 10/10 sigils" (Although it didn't manage to find the eleventh secret sigil)

PS: Dog is fine!"

reviewText:
The Talos Principle. In the vast selection of video games to buy, the Talos Principle shines brighter than most games. It's quite simple at first: use the jammer to jam walls and enemies. But as you progress, more and more puzzle elements are unlocked or discovered, making the puzzles harder and harder.

Some puzzles with red sigils as rewards are more difficult than the norm, and can even help the player unlock parts of the game later on.

And let us not forget Elohim and his plethora of robot followers. Elohim is on your side. He will promise you eternal life as long as you never climb the great tower. And the fellow followers cannot be encountered in-game, but you can find their thoughts and feelings in the form of QR codes. When the HUD is selected over the QR, a box will appear and you will encounter text from the others. They are pretty funny sometimes. And, if you have friends who play the Talos Principle, you can encounter THEIR QR codes that THEY wrote! Sadly, you cannot make your own, you must select from the options provided, but it's still fun to encounter a friend of yours saying they want to meet you at the top of the tower.

As the puzzles get harder and harder, will you be able to handle the difficulty.

Solid 10/10, better than most next-gen graphics games.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText: If you like Portal, this is a must (if you haven't played Portal, get it and this both). Not only it's full of entertaining puzzles, it also gives the player the chance to learn more about the world the game is set in. If you like a good story you'll enjoy looking for terminals and reading the documents you find, if not, you can just skip it all. A big plus is that almost all of the puzzles aren't timed so you can take your time thinking about it and, if you are stuck and unable to solve one of the puzzles, you can just leave and go solve another one. A negative side for this game is it's graphics: while the areas themselves are beautiful, there isn't much variation and after doing few puzzles in the same level, it starts looking boring and dull. Also, at least at the time I played it (few months ago), only few of the latest save files were preserved, so, if you wished to revert back to some time ago (to try different choices, check different endings), you had to backup them manually. Overall, I'd give it a score of 9/10.

reviewText:
The Talos Principle deserves a spot right next to Portal as an all-time great.  It is a first person puzzle game in the same vein, where your guide poses as a diety guiding you to salvation.  The narrative is highly philisophical as you complete puzzles and try to figure out the where and why of your situation, in contrast to Portal's very humorous tone.

This game was quite a surprise, coming from Croteam who are best known for the over the top oldschool FPS series Serious Sam which is purely about shooting monsters and bad jokes.  The Serious Sam influence is obvious in the graphical style (it uses the same engine as well) but otherwise there is no resemblance.  It is a great-looking and smooth-running game with a ridiculous number of options thanks to Croteam's Serious Engine.  Being their first puzzle game, it's quite a feat for them to create such a superb experience.

But to the game itself:  Puzzles are arranged in hub worlds, which you can visit at your leisure.  If you can't figure one out, you can go find another and come back to it later.  You solve puzzles using a rather unique set of tools from laser beams to the ability to record a temporary copy of yourself.  At the end of each puzzle is a tetromino sigil (tetris piece) that need to later be arranged in panels to unlock various content.  Easy sigils unlock more puzzle areas, medium sigils unlock more tools to solve puzzles with, while hard sigils allow you to ascend the tower in the main hub world.  There are also hidden star sigils scattered throughout the game you can collect to unlock additional puzzles which can be very difficult to locate.

I found the puzzles to be very well-designed with a pretty smooth difficulty curve.  The stars however are a mixed bag.  For some reason, stars in the earlier, easier areas of the game are far more difficult to locate and obtain than those in the later, generally more difficult areas.  They'll be hidden in a tiny alcove in a giant map filled with ruins that have no purpose for puzzles, or require connecting lasers to hidden/invisible objects.  Later stars are often in plain view, and just require some extra thinking to reach.  I will admit I had to look at guides a few times just to figure out where the stars were, much less obtain them.

It's hard to say much more without being in danger of spoiling the story.  There is a ton of information in the game in the form of text and audio lore that is available if you are the sort of person who likes that.  Personally I found myself skipping over most of the text lore simply because there is so much of it and I wanted to get back to the puzzles, though it seems to be very well-written.

TL;DR: If you want a first person puzzle game of a similar quality level as Portal, but with significantly more content than Portal 2, look no further.  The $40 asking price is a bargain for what this game offers.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The Talos Principle gets my vote for Best Overall Game of the Year 2014.

Going into it, I didn't think I would ever say that, but it blew away all my expectations. Everything about this title is masterfully done. Once I picked this title up on a Saturday morning, I literally didn't do much else until I saw the ending on Monday morning. Yep, its that good.

Here is why you owe it to yourself to play this:

The game plays a *bit* like Portal, although the references are really not that necessary since The Talos Principle is certainly its own game. Yes, there are puzzles and yes, it is FPS perspective. Yes it also has an interesting storyline, but it takes itself much more seriously. The puzzles are way harder IMO, and the storyline is much, much deeper and overall fleshed out. Whats really cool about the puzzles, is that they will force you to think in a way you never have, and you will get good at it! This will allow you to solve them quicker as you progress, which makes you feel like a boss***.

Graphically, this game is a beast. Every scene is a postcard. Seriously. Even more, the devs reward you by exploring. Oh
date: look at the beautiful beach behind this flippin' castle that has nothing to do with the game - oh wow there is loot here!". The music is nothing short of epic either. Trust me on this - I cranked it the whole time.\n\nThe best part about this gem is the storyline. This is literally the most masterful writing I have ever read in a videogame. I have been chronically gaming since the mid '80s. The game is text-heavy for sure
recommended: but it will have you craving even more. All the philosophy is based in reality (most appeared cited
hoursPlayed: as well)
voteText: which fed the armchair philosopher in me. I mean this game is part Biblical

votesHelpful: and overall spiritual.  It will make you think.\n\nFunny thing is

reviewText: This game is a masterpiece. Deep, interesting, moving storyline married with polished, beatifully realised gameplay. The graphics are beautiful, albeit heavy on the lense-flare at times. reviewText: If Serious Sam had a brain maybe he could escape the world of Elohim and all its puzzles that are like Russian dolls. Unfortunately he has none so they decided to send a robot instead.\nThe Talos principle is a very nice game that gives you the freedom to solve each room almost in the order you prefer. The difficulty ramps up slowly and you can always get help. You'll find out how ;-). The voice that guides you and all the messages you will find on the monitors gives some depth to the story. And the maps are full of nice Easter eggs that will make you smile when you find them.\nIf you liked the portal series, the Talos principle is for you. It is not as good because it lacks some verticality and of course a portal gun. But the esoteric part compensates it somehow.

reviewText:
This is the best game i have ever played in my life.
the graphics are incredible, the soundtrack is beautiful, the voicing is excellent and so on...
this game is mainly a puzzler (and a particularily hard one at that), but also has a lot of other things in mind, paticularily philosophy and the great question of existence: there are computer terminals dotted around the landscape that tell stories and will sometimes ask you questions (difficult ones) about why you think humans should be all equal, or what your purpose is in life.
Other great features in this game are the stars, probably my favourite puzzles, which are completely out of the ordinary and leave you dumbfounded the first time you see them. So far i have 10 with no help (proud) and the easter eggs. I wont say anything about them so i dont spoil the game, but i can promise that there are plenty and are all clever references to other great games.
the ONLY problem with this game is its lack of humour (wich to tell the truth it doesnt even need)
anyway BUY THIS GAME

reviewText: The Talos Principle is an absolutely extraordinary puzzle game. It marries complex, compelling puzzle design with a sophisticated science fiction story told through intelligent writing. It doesn't waste your time, and it will expect you to be actively thinking in order to solve many of its puzzles.\n\nSeriously, if you dig sci-fi and puzzle games, you owe it to yourself to get this. The story is interesting enough that it's been stuck in my head for days, and the puzzles are at that special level of quality where I've actually picked out a few favorites based on how well-paced they were and how interesting the logical jumps were that they required. For the record my favorite puzzle in the game (after having solved all the puzzles one would solve on a base-level playthrough and only a few of the extra star puzzles) is Prison Break. You'll know it when you see it. It's fascinating and a ton of fun, which I guess is also the phrase I'd use to describe The Talos Principle as a whole.

reviewText:
I write this review after 12 hours of gameplay and I _suppose_ I'm past the half of the game without counting optional challenges.

- If you liked Portal, buy this game immediately
- If you kinda liked Portal but found it a bit hard when dexterity was needed, buy this game immediately too as almost all puzzles don't need any dexterity nor speed
- If you liked Antichamber buy this game too :)

A bit more information :
- the visuals are simple but beautiful
- difficulty ramp-up is well balanced and optional puzzles can really be challenging
- the philosophic plot about humanity, tech and religion might seem a bit dull a the beginning but the more I advance to more I want to know.
- tons of references about all kind of things (tech, sciences, culture, social, internet, even warez)
- I even just came across an optional puzzle which is kinda cross media, genius idea !!! Even if, I suppose, it will stay exceptional and it's probably a good thing.

One final thought, I usually wait steam sales to by a game on steam, and I did for this one (-30%) as I didn't know if it would fulfill my expectations. 40 bucks when I usually buy games at an average of 10-15 with most indie games was hard to accept.

Today I can assure you I would gladly pay full price knowing the pleasure I'm having with this game.

reviewText:
Tremendous game, really can't recommend it more.

Like everyone says, comparisons to Portal 2 abound in the genre, but if you can get away from that mindset it's got a lot to offer, and not just from the puzzles.  Outside of the more elementary gameplay mechanics the plot is just generally good SciFi. And simple mechanics used in a new way are what drive classic games

It's very obvious, at least to me, that this game is going to be as culturally significant to the genre as the Portal titles were. It might take just a bit longer to get to the point that the plot engages your interest, but once you understand what it is all about you will be impressed.

So far 2015 seems to be the year decent SciFi makes a comeback.

reviewText:
Wow, this game.

If you have any interest in puzzle games in the style of Portal 2, try this one (Portal 1 was more platforming oriented).

The puzzles are sublime, they will make you tear your hair and then doubt your mental health once you finish them. They are all completely obvious yet freaking hard to figure out.

While there is a bit of platforming involved the puzzles are really not about the execution as once you know what to do its generally easy to do it (still you will fail a lot).

The game does a very good job at teaching you the mechanics through 3 difficulty levels of puzzles green, yellow and red. Yet it still leaves some mechanics to be discovered (mainly if you want to get all the elusive hidden stars). Once you get bored with the puzzles there are tons of easter eggs hidden all through the game.

As a puzzle game, this game mainly stands on its mechanics and excellent puzzle design. However the story creates an excellent counterpoint and its presentation will leave you wanting more and more and more and will keep you thinking about what could be possible going on in this strange world.

The game has three distinct endings (plus some variants). You will get 20 hours (at the very least) from this game if you don’t quit halfway through.

reviewText:
This is an absurdly good game, and I really think it needs even more praise than it's gotten so that these devs will want to make more.

The writing in this game alone is perhaps some of the best in video gaming history and really elevates this game towards 'art' (not that that pretentious distinction is something that is necessary, but I think most non-gamer observers could see something going on here beyond that which occurs in most games). The visual art and gameplay complement the writing fabulously. I don't want to give too many specific examples because the worst thing I could do is spoil the experience. The game world is full of discovery, philosophy, and deep reflection, along with some wicked satisfying puzzles.

Carried myself on myself and got Socratic dialog b**** slapped by a librarian 10/10 would throw money at a sequel with this much care and thoughtfulness.

reviewText: A good puzzle is one that communicates its ideas very clearly and uninterruptedly, and most of the puzzles I've solved so far in Talos Principle are exactly like that - very short, sweet and extremely on-point. You can hardly ever find any obfuscation or misleading elements that will disrupt your stream of problem solving. Each puzzle has its own isolated and confined space and you will never be able to use elements from one puzzle to cheat in another (well if you aren't purposefully looking to exploit glitches anyway).\n\n♥♥♥♥in' amazin'.

reviewText:
Very good puzzle game with a good amount of puzzles that didn't go stale. This game had one of my favorite puzzle elements that I'd never seen before which was that you could make a recording of yourself that would interact with the puzzle world as well. In this way, it almost felt like single player coop, which was a lot of fun. The game had a lot of substance, but I wish it had more of the hard puzzles. There were a few hard ones that stumped me for a while. I wish they had more difficult puzzles though, because the ones they had were really rewarding.

The story was very good, and was presented in such a way that you could skip the parts of the story you didn't care for. Music and graphics were good, but I would have enjoyed some tesselation so the ground and walls would have a bit more of a feel to them. For what it's worth, the design and layouts were pretty nice, so the flatness wasn't so bad.

I'd highly recommend this game, but I'd say there is one thing I find disappointing about it. The disappointment is that it would benefit greatly from something like a map generator like in Portal 2. At this point the game is done, and it was awesome to play, but there's not much left for me to do with it.

reviewText: It's not flawless, but it's exceptional.\nAt heart Talos Principle is a thought provoking secular humanism manifesto that gracefully presents its reasoning. It's aptly avoiding excessive didactism. It's philosophical core is wraped in a blanket of cleverly written, engaging story and elegant (but sometimes lacking) puzzle solving gameplay.\nI find it very awkward to recommend a game -despite- its gameplay, but Talos Principle surely deserves Your time. I hope its unprecedented level of writing will set a new standard for the games to come.

reviewText:
1/3 first- or third-person puzzle game
1/3 intro to philosophy course
1/3 spiritual experience

This is easily one of the best games I've played in years; it completely blew me away. Not since Portal have I been this enamored with a first-person puzzle game. I'd even go one step further and claim that it was better than the Portal games. Yes... it's that good.

I was not prepared for just how beautiful the game is. It is readily apparent that every square inch of the world was painstakingly crafted to give us the best experience possible. From Medieval ruins, to sprawling desert, to towering cathederals -- The Talos Principle is guaranteed to make you stare at your screen in awe at least once.

If you like first-person puzzle games, play The Talos Principle.
If you like puzzle games with more narrative than usual, play The Talos Principle.
If you love finding in-game secrets, play The Talos Principle.
Play The Talos Principle.

reviewText: Talos Principle is a game where you don't shoot anything and, speaking (actually writing) as someone who rather likes games where you shoot things, I can see why it's not been too popular. But suppress all that gung-ho bloodlust for a few hours (or 20) and you'll find TP is actually a refreshing experience, if by refreshing you mean running round one arena for twenty minutes wondering why you are one cube short. The reason - as always in this game - is because you're an idiot and have learned nothing.\nThe learning curve is shallow at the start until you realise just how many puzzles there are, in addition to the easter eggs, puzzles behind secret doors, puzzles in distant places, and puzzles within (and often outside of) other puzzles. By the later stages, you're setting up cobweb-like networks of light beams, turning one block into two, travelling through time to stand on your own head and - when things go wrong - wondering where all the beams are going, which door just opened (or closed), watching essential objects fly back and forth through the air and (I kid you not) wondering whether to learn ASCII just to make sense of it all. Several times after wondering how I just did what I did, the follow-up thought was: 'how did someone write something that devious?'\nIt's all a little Portal, or perhaps a bloated Portal (but still challenging: Portal 2 take note), which is no bad thing. There's also a lot of reading waffle about consciousness and stuff which you can entirely ignore. But that's a puzzle game for you: brain over brawn; and at least if you run naked down the street wielding an axe and screaming I am the word and the world is the words"

reviewText:
This game is not only a finely-crafted puzzle game but a work of art that drives the player to think deeply not just when solving spacial puzzles and patterns, but when contemplating the very facets of their existence, consciousness, moral code, and sense of self. The game boils down complex philosophical texts and concepts in a way very digestible by non-philosophers.

This game moved me, and I found myself spending late nights pondering the meaning of what I had read. It's been a very long time since I bought a game and became so hooked that I played it through to the finish in just a week or two without really playing anything else. The puzzles fall under muscle memory in time, and they become busywork for your hands as your thoughts linger on the curiosity and emotion spawned from ingame computer messages and voice logs. The game affects you as much as you allow it to. The more you think on the concepts presented, the more you find parallels in real life. I can name at least three things this game has changed my view on in real life, and many more things that I felt have been reinforced. Not since college classes have I been driven to have such internal conversations on existential topics.

The puzzles are also the single weak point of the game, as the tetromino puzzles grow frustratingly boring. They appear whenever unlocking particular secret zones and some of the late-game content for some of the possible endings. They get so long-winded and frustrating that they outright interrupt the otherwise beautifully-crafted trains of thought and emotion the game guides you along. But that's a part of it--the frustration. I understand the reason behind the mechanic, but I still feel like it's a bit TOO real--a bit too harsh a method of teaching patience and perseverance.

Anyone looking for an intelligent and wholly inspiring game should buy this. It's not flashy, it's not exciting (until the end!), and it's definitely more niche as it requires patience and attentiveness in a way very few games do...but beating this game was the most educational video game experience I've had, and easily one of the most fulfilling. The graphics and environments are beautiful, the voice acting is remarkable, and the pacing of the game is spot-on. You can tell the developers playtested the game rigorously, and they know very well the many ways players will approach The Talos Principle's challenges...and boy does that really drive the narrative.

As for me, I'm off to buy the DLC and blow my mind a second time.

Thank you, Croteam.

reviewText:
This portal-like has a good habit of making the player think outside the box in more ways than one. Puzzles are unique, challenging yet fair, and well-executed. There seems to have been special attention taken to keep players from cheesing the challenges, although it is possible.

Narrative-wise, it is a bit deeper than many games. It might have you thinking a little more about what it means to be a human, a person, or even conscious. That said, you can skip all of it and still derive significant entertainment from this game.

Graphically, it is the same level as Serious Sam 3, which makes a lot of sense as it reuses tons of assets from that title. It's not a bad thing. Just efficient really.

The voice acting is up to snuff, although I didn't hear as much from Elohim as I could have as I was using the Sam Voice DLC for around two-thirds of the game.

If you want a well executed puzzle game that will leave you satisfied, then this one will not leave you disappointed.

Special note: The reward of the stars is mostly the satisfaction of solving puzzles. Just a heads up.

The puzzles are quite satisfying to figure out, and some really make you rethink your strategy. In each puzzle, usually every single piece is used somewhere causing the player to thoroughly analyze the situation.

I definitely recommend it to any of you that like puzzle games, AI, and philosophy.
Also the music is great.

reviewText: Greater than the sum of its parts, The Talos Principle is an excellent addition to the puzzle genre, one that's challenging but always fair, easy to play but always mysterious. The visuals are super clean and colorful. The quantity of puzzles is staggering. Weird as it may seem in a game like this, the story is actually the thing I remember the most. Specifically, the conversations with the Milton Library Assistant are engaging and sometimes unpleasant. You just have to experience it for yourself.\n\nThis is still a puzzle game through and through, and solving these puzzles is what you'll spend 90% of your time doing. Every puzzle mechanic is used with each other in every combination quite nicely, and the game allows for a lot of freedom when it comes to which puzzle you want to attempt next. The only downside to The Talos Principle is the overused puzzle involving tetris pieces. When tackled sporadically they aren't too bad, but they could've used a bit more variety. This is an excellent puzzle game that will challenge you with its puzzles and please you with its graphics and atmosphere. Highly recommend.

reviewText:
I have now finished the main game twice and the Road To Gehenna DLC once, and discovered all of their endings. It's been incredibly enjoyable and rewarding; not far into the game I could see why this game has received overwhelmingly positive reviews here on Steam.

Not only are the puzzles well-designed, but the setting and story is intriguing and encourages you to think and contemplate what you think you know. It's also up to you to figure out a lot of the story, and throughout the game there are consequential decisions to be made. As I mentioned earlier, there are multiple endings to both the game and the DLC, but there are also different versions of those endings dependent on your choices throughout the game (I have yet to unlock one achievement that affects one of the endings).

The Road To Gehenna DLC offers you an increased difficulty in puzzles to solve, and a very intriguing approach to storytelling; as in the main game, it is up to you to be interested in acquiring the full extent of the story.

I headed into both the main game and the DLC without any prior expectations or knowledge about them, and I am glad I did. If you enjoy problem-solving, science-fiction, mythology, and philosophy, you will enjoy this.

reviewText:
There is truly no way to recommend this game enough. Gives rise to some SERIOUS existential thinking, it's absolutely beautiful to look at and challenging to even long term fans of the puzzle genre. The story is lightweight in the way it's presented to you (it's not forced down your throat, and you could pretty much ignore it if you really wanted to) but is compelling and has several times during the game very much moved me
Absolutely the only downside is that the puzzles have only a few mechanics, but even this is overcome by the way in which the level design is put together - what you thought you knew from that puzzle a few levels ago is pretty much the same in this one, but disguised in such a way that its hard to tell you've only recently done pretty much the same thing.

Demo doesn't have any story hooks, but shows the gameplay well - I bought the game based off this alone and I regret not one single penny!

reviewText:
The Talos Principle is a game I'd strongly recommend. I was initially hesitant due to the price, and eventually got it on special. Having now completed the game, I can honestly say that it is well worth the full price! This game is an absolute gem, and I cannot recommend it strongly enough! To aid in your decisions for purchasing this game I've broken down my review into positives, negatives, and points that are neither strongly positive or negative.

The Positives
The gameplay mechanics themselves. The game concepts are, in themselves, incredibly straightforward -- it takes almost no time whatsoever to learn how to make use of each object you are presented. However, while straightforward to learn, the concepts are extremely difficult to master. While the early levels in the game may seem outright trivial, some of the later ones will really leave you scratching your head!

Hidden stars. While the game itself is all about collecting the sigils, there is actually another type of collectible -- stars. The star puzzles are far, *far* harder to complete than the original puzzles. If you thought the main game was too easy, try and collect each of the stars. Some of the more challenging stars will literally take you *hours* to work out how to obtain!

Multiple solutions to puzzles. Due to what I can only assume is brilliant level design, each solution to each puzzle is roughly as difficult to achieve. You may not end up solving a puzzle the way that was intended, but your method certainly won't be a cakewalk!

Multiple endings. There are three unique endings to The Talos Principle. Will you ascend the tower, or resist its temptation? Or perhaps you will explore the lands to find all the hidden secrets, and unlock a third ending?

Decisions galore! In addition to the main puzzle-solving gameplay, there is an integral AI that can be spoken to through the terminals scattered throughout the worlds. The AI will often ask you questions that have multiple answers. Each answer branches out into a response that will contain another question with a completely different set of answers.

The psychological and philosophical aspect. The Talos Principle has the player answer questions that delve deep into psychology and philosophy. These questions range from discussions over whether liberty or freedom is more important, to subjective views on what it means to be human. These questions are so deep that you're bound to learn something about yourself.

Outright promotion of the thought process required to break many games. While each puzzle in the Talos Principle is self-contained, to achieve many of the hidden stars you will have to break some of the levels by either smuggling items in or smuggling items out. As long as there's not an obstacle in the way, you essentially have free reign in the worlds.

Easter eggs galore! There are literally *dozens* of hidden Easter eggs contained in The Talos Principle. These Easter eggs are so masterfully hidden that even the exploration veterans will struggle to find them.

Building upon classics games in a way that honours each.You use cubes and lasers to open doors, akin to Portal. There are hidden stars to collect, akin to Super Mario 64. You use the sigils you collect to unlock locks by assembling them in a way similar to Tetris. Not only does The Talos Principle pay homage to such games, but utilises their concepts in a way that said games would be proud of.

Stunning graphics! Throughout the game, you'll travel from Greek ruins, to ancient Egypt, to Nordic fortresses and English castles. The variety makes for a difficult combination of animations, yet each one is done absolutely beautifully. Each location feels crisp, and really adds to the atmosphere.

True gameplay and performance customisation. While many games have the ability to change things like aspect ratio and graphics settings, The Talos Principle takes settings customisation to lengths that I have *never* seen in any other game. There are separate customisations menus for both the CPU and GPU! From adjusting the brightness and gamma, to lighting in reflections, to four different types of antialiasing, to the type of filter used for rescaling, The Talos Principle allows you to customise every last little performance detail.

Road To Gehenna DLC. The Road To Gehenna changes protagonist, leads you to brand new lands, adds much harder puzzles, and fleshes out the original story. On top of all that, it *dramatically* fleshes out the terminal systems. Instead of chatting to the regular AI, you now play a user of a messageboard system created by the residents of Gehenna. Performing certain actions on the messageboards allow you to rank-up in the system, which in turn allows you to read private topics that reveal more about the world around you. There's *multiple* MUD games to play through the messageboards, each of which are thoroughly enjoyable. Honestly, the Road To Gehenna is such an amazing DLC that it could be released as a stand-alone game!
The Neutral
Star locations. While I love the concept of the stars and the challenge of obtaining them, I feel as though there is a bit of a disconnect in their physical locations. Stars can be in individual levels, the outer worlds, or even the hubs. Each world shows how many stars are in it, but gives absolutely no clue as to whether they are in certain levels or the outer world itself. Some of these stars are hidden *very* well.The challenge really should be in working out out how to *get* the star, not how to *find* the star.

The audio. There's a few fairly generic, laid-back audio tracks in the game. While they work well for adventuring and solving the puzzles, there is very limited variety. It would have been nice to have a bit more tension for some of the harder puzzles, or at least a few tracks in different genres. Naturally, you can always mute the game and play your own music if you'd prefer.

The save system. The game auto-saves often, which is great if the game crashes. There are a number of different auto-save slots, but there is no option to make a manual save. One of the endings thrusts you right back into the start of the game, and you can easily accidentally overwrite your progress if you progress too far.
The Negatives
The story that doesn't really feel very fleshed-out. Both the opening cutscene and closing cutscenes are very short compared to most modern games. As you progress, a bit of the reasoning behind you being there and information about the world itself are revealed, but it still feels as though the game would have benefited from longer cutscenes.

Rare instances wherein objects become unusable. At one point I put down a jammer and for some reason I was completely unable to pick it back up. I couldn't interact with anything in the level, and was forced to restart the level.

High thresholds for performance options. While there is an absolute plethora of customisation options for performance, The Talos Principle tries to set a benchmark based on your computer specifications. Unfortunately, this benchmark is a little high. I've got a fairly decent computer, so my graphics settings were set to 'Ultra' by default. This caused some lag spikes in some situations, and even resulted in the game presenting me a BSOD at one point.
All in all, I'd give The Talos Principle a 9.5/10. This is one of the best games that I have played in a *long* time, and one that should definitely be picked up!

reviewText:
The Talos Principle. A philosophical science fiction puzzle game made by the developers of Serious Sam. I really like it.

The game looks so beautiful and it runs pretty darn well. I have 280X and i7 2600k and I've set everything almost to the max, solid 60FPS. It also probably has the biggest amount of graphics and physics settings of all games I've ever played and I've played a lot of games. You can change everything from transparency anti-aliasing to ambient occulsion precision.

Gameplay. The character movement is superb. It's like in Source games (eg. CS:GO), moving the camera with mouse is presice as laser beam and walking and strafing around with WASD just feels so good.

And then two main points in the whole game and this review.

Puzzles, they are excellent like in Portal 2 and in its modification, Portal Stories: Mel. At first, they are pretty easy but still fun to do. Things will get slowly harder and harder, but don't get me wrong, hard =/= frustrating, it's still fun! As you progress you will unlock new puzzle tools and a lot more complex puzzles in different locations all around the world.

And the second main point, its story. Like I said, it's a philosophical science fiction puzzle game. I don't want to spoil too much but the game makes you think more about artificial intelligence, faith and yourself. At first you probably just think that you are in some kind of a heaven (or hell?) where some god speaks to you and is about to give you an eternal life if you can prove your faith and bla bla. But it's so much more than that. When you advance, you'll start to find pieces of information about the past, other people and things that have happened. Maybe it's not heaven after all, it's something much much worse (or better). But lets not spoil too much. Just buy it and start playing. You will get hooked, you can't stop playing.

Oh, and did I already mention that there are absolutely no loading times anywhere!

tl;dr One of the best puzzle games I've ever played. It's like Portal 2 (and Portal Stories: Mel). A really really good puzzle game with strong story and it's well ♥♥♥♥ing optimized.

reviewText:
The intersection of story-driven gameplay and puzzle mechanics too often results in clunky, confusing interruptions to the flow of otherwise excellent and immersive narrative experiences. Puzzles may be absurdly easy and seem entirely out of place (e.g. Skyrim), needlessly lengthening parts of the game, or their extreme difficulty may grind gameplay to a halt (e.g. Silent Hill series). However, just as Valve so brilliantly defied this rule with the Portal series years ago, Croteam manage in The Talos Principle to seamlessly integrate an interesting plot, as well as a mystifying lore, with absolutely exceptional puzzles. And where Portal and its sequel excel in wit and ironic humour, The Talos Principle achieves profundity, treating meaningfully and thoughtfully the most fundamental questions of philosophy and ethics, without being pretentious. The texts and audio files found throughout the world constitute a fully realized and intriguing lore, and dialogue with the Milton character is fascinating and thought-provoking; however, the game never forces any philosophy, or even the discussion of philosophy at all, upon the player. It made my experience richer by a hundredfold, but if it's not quite your cup of tea, and you're playing simply for the joy of the puzzles, then you may ignore it and skip it all and still have a perfectly wonderful experience.

Everything about this game, from its user interface and its world design, is absolutely beautiful (the last world, the Land of Faith, is the most striking). However, encountering over and over again very similarly designed ruins can, after many hours in the same world, leave one with a dull impression. The mechanics are smooth and seamless, without any of the usual annoyances or hitches, such as slow movement and limited sprinting. The puzzles themselves are progressively and rewardingly challenging, and, unlike so many other puzzle games, non-linear. Some of the game's more complex puzzles actually have multiple possible solutions, even incorporating one's solutions to other puzzles in the same level, and, if one gets stuck, a puzzle may be skipped and saved for later (up to a point, of course). Finally, the conclusion quite perfectly wraps up the narrative and allows the player a glimpse behind the veil of the lore, as the developers offer their own answer to question underlying it all: What does it mean to be human?"

To anyone who loves thoughtful puzzles and thoughtful narrative
date: I wholeheartedly recommend this masterpiece of design and concept.\n\n10/10 - Superb"

reviewText: The Talos principle is a very intelligent,extremely fun puzzle game.Each puzzle has its own unique way of solving it with the different tools that you're given.The game urges you to outsmart yourself and there are no words to explain the satisfaction you get on completing each puzzle that in no time you'l be craving for more.Added to that it makes you ponder over your existence,the different aspects of life, and what it means to be a human.In this way the game is also about philosophy.It takes so much creativity,hardwork and sheer talent to create a game like this.For that i can only admire its developers for their ingenuity.I highly recommend this game to all the puzzle lovers,science enthusiasts and philosophers out there.Simply one of the best gaming experiences I ever had.

reviewText:
Good game, similar to Portal, but definitely not at the same level.

Let's start with what I think were mistakes on this game:
- they failed on the Law of Conservation of Energy during the narration (or at least the Italian translation did, badly) and since the whole game is about AI this is really bad IMHO
- puzzles are repetitive, to a point that for more than half of the puzzles everything is reduced to the hassle of running around with the pieces (and/or falling/else because you're bored and you don't pay attention anymore) of a puzzle you solved as you entered the room because you've already solved that same puzzle before, with minor differences
- narration is slow... actually it's a direct consequence of the exaggerated amount of puzzles needed to beat the game

So why isn't my review negative? Because, again, the game is good.
The plot, even though it's smeared on almost 20 hours of game-play, is nice and catching with all the reasoning, philosophy and physics. Graphics are top notch (mostly) and anyway always visually rewarding. Same could be said for the soundtrack that was never able to bore me even if I was listening to it for 20 hours straight. Probably something more could have been done on sound effects, sometimes they felt repetitive or missing.

I'd like to talk a bit more about those puzzles, because the concept is great, and the realization is great too, when I was given a puzzle I had to think to solve it was fun and rewarding, but then I was given the same puzzle, with minor differences that took me a minute or less to understand and I lost tenth of minutes just running around with puzzle pieces, bored, so bored I'd actually fail falling or being killed because I was rushing to end the thing ASAP, furthermore increasing the boredom adding some frustration.
And again, certain puzzles were great and on others I even gave up (more or less 1/3 of the stars") so challenging they were
date: I just cannot stand this "same puzzle over and over" thing
recommended: sorry. Not to mention that to beat the game you HAVE to complete all the puzzles (except for the "stars").\n\nTo conclude
hoursPlayed: in my opinion this game could have been on the same level of Portal if it had 1/3 of the puzzles it has (or even less)

reviewText:
The Talos Principle is a first person puzzle game that allows players to assume the role of a sentient artificial intelligence placed within a simulation of humanity's greatest ruins and linked together through an arcane cathedral. Players are tasked with solving a series of increasingly complex puzzles woven into a metaphysical parable about intelligence and meaning in an inevitably doomed world.
Stunningly beautiful visuals, astonishing and peaceful environments and amazing soundtrack are perfectly combined creating a harmonious and relaxing atmosphere. The story is quite intriguing and mainly given through voice and text archives, fragments of mythology, science, literature, history and personal information such as letters and audio diaries.
This game features multiple endings while also addressing religious subjects, although it's strictly allegorical, metaphorical and plot-driven.
I highly recommend The Talos Principle aswell as Road to Gehenna DLC.

reviewText: I've been playing video games for around 10 years, and  'The Talos Principle' will forever sit on my super-star tag-team of my favorite games of all time. reviewText:
A first person puzzle adventure that builds a world around excellent puzzle design with a fantastic and engaging philosophical backstory that wont let go of your interest and curiosity.

From my very first moments of exploring and interacting with the world, I knew I'd found something I was going to enjoy, and while the level of design and subtle mood are all work to set the game up incredibly well, there are some subtle interwoven design choices that make this title something special, and it took me a lot of playtime to figure out why I enjoyed The Talos Principle beyond just being an excellent first person Puzzle game with rich story. Things like the writing work hand in hand with the overlying story to create depth and intrigue at an early stage and make you want to progress more than any other game I've played in recent memory.

Highlights
The subtle gameplay and level design choices throughout The Talos Principle are so incredibly well done that the first playthrough is nothing short of incredibly engaging fun. You're taught to interact with the world and not take anything for granted which means you're unaware that you're improving and more importantly unaware that you're thinking in a different way and genuinely unlocking different avenues of thought in your own mind.
Terminals, for example, contain short segments of text that serve the overall narrative, but also change pitch every so often, and coupled with the mythological, religious and historical tales and references and things like recordings scattered throughout the world, you'll often unknowingly have expectations of what's expected of you. The writing and design set up a box then encourages you to think outside of it and it makes everything more rewarding.

Other subtle changes like the complete lack of timed puzzles which make up the vast majority of other titles, and the lack of direct linear progression, and lack of any direct demand of the player to continue means we progress in the game of our own accord, and it helps us tie ourselves into the story and feel part of the world.

* The sheer technical design and tuning which show off more of the stellar design is impressive. Cross platform support, console access and inside mod support, outside mod support for Steam Workshop and more all add replayability to an already lengthy title.
* There wide array of configuration options deserve praise, you can adjust almost any aspect of the technicals.

Mistakes & Annoyances
The biggest annoyance of this game is the standard it sets for itself early on, and in not maintaining the incredible level of curiosity and quality of writing up until the end. It's hard to complain about a game offering this much content and length, but when the latter third of the game doesn't hold up as much as the first third, it can feel slightly weary or repetitive at times to continue.

* Due to the somewhat floaty movement and bright colour scheme, it's very easy to feel nausea or motion sickness while playing this game, though there are an impressive set of tools to adjust these settings under an aptly named Motion Sickness sub-menu

Recommendations
Priced at £29.99/39.99€/$39.99 and only 19.99€ in Steam European Region 2, The Talos Principle is at the top range of what I'm personally willing to pay for a video game, and more expensive than related games like Portal 2, and even more than the inflated prices of some of the triple A titles. As a result, I find it hard to call this good value for everyone, but because of the very well designed and polished gameplay and the average play time of at least 16 hours, people paying full price are not going to feel ripped off and if you're the target market, someone who enjoys first person puzzle games with a great backstory and interesting details, it's a good buy even at full price. For the rest of us, I'd suggest it's worth waiting for a sale of -50% or more.

* The Road To Gehenna DLC adds four new episodes with much harder difficulty (but by no means cheap in approach, nor needlessly difficult) with an open approach and a different take on the game and an equally great and interesting story/narrative. None of this is just more-of-the-same and it's a great DLC worth buying for people who have already enjoyed the full game. Fairly priced at £10.99/14.99€/$14.99, as with the main game, cheapest from EU2.
* The Serious DLC adds a Serious Sam character model and a new voice for Elohim and may be worth £1.99/2.99€/$2.99 for Serious Sam fans, but is a waste of time otherwise considering other models and skins are available free within the Steam Workshop.
* The Prototype DLC adds 100+ puzzles, the majority of which are simply recycled designs from the pre-alpha to release of the game. You'll revisit many levels from the main game with flaws or without nice modelling/background and as a result may feel like you're wasting time or being cheated. There is one exclusive world included, and this DLC offers support for many Steam Workshop mods and offers two new Elohim voice-overs. If you can put up with retreading old maps with annoying issues, it may be worth the £3.99/4.99€/$4.99

* A free demo is available on the Store page for anyone still on the fence.
* Check the Steam Workshop after completing the game where you can find a number of skins (Companion Cube Hexahedrons anyone?) and more maps.
* There's a prelude game available on Steam called Sigils of Elohim featuring a number of the Sigil formation puzzles. It's available for free and includes 12 Relics for The Talos Principle.

reviewText:
This game was an absolute gem to play and deserves a place on everyone's bucket list.  Combining Portal-esque puzzle mechanics with deep philosophical themes was a brilliant move on Croteam's part and it made for a video game experience unlike any other.  The puzzles are very fun to solve and never once did I feel overly frustrated by any unfair game design.  Even the hard-to-obtain bonus secrets are cleverly hidden as intriguing challenges, encouraging out of the box thinking in a variety of unexpected ways.

The story is mainly told through text and audio logs left behind throughout the world, letting you slowly uncover the truth of those before you.  As I progressed through the game, I was constantly pondering the nature of being human, and hearing godly voice of Elohim affirm or deny my beliefs was an wondrous experience.  Though the character I controlled was a robot, I found the story to be astonishingly human, making for one of the greatest video game narratives I have ever experienced.

Did I mention the graphics and art design are oh-so-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gorgeous?  Also, I was able to run the game smoothly on my mediocre laptop and still maintain great visual quality.

If you like using your brain and deliberating a little philosophy, then you should already know what to do:

BUY
THIS
GAME

reviewText:
Bought this game when it was on a weekend sale and can definitely say I am thoroughly impressed.

It is a puzzle game which plays similar (in very select ways) to Portal, such as the depth of puzzles to solve, variety of puzzles and intriguing and engaging story. The Talos Principle has an incredible amount of depth in its story design, depth which you can only appreciate if you take the time to do a lot of reading, and a lot of witty and philisophical discussion with a computer personality who accompanies you throughout the campaign.

In my one playthrough I spent 20 solid hours on it and only really started to feel it be recycling puzzle ideas towards the end. Regardless, it was worth the 9.99USD that I paid for it and I would probably say it is reasonable at full price if you know that this game (from reading about it) is going to be one which you will engage with. If you are only looking for a puzzle game than the full price may be a bit to steep.

Very impressed, would recommend.

reviewText:
A Paladin’s Review: The Talos Principle. This Review and The Game We Are Looking At Are Made of Words.Genre: Single Player First/Third Person Puzzler, Story Driven with Philosophical Topics.
Developed & Published by: Croteam and Devolver Digital
Platform: Windows, Mac, Linux, Android and PS4
Business Model: Single Purchase + Expansion DLC
Copy Purchased by Myself Read the full & unabridged review that can't fit in Steam reviews on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]

Overall Gameplay Thoughts
The Talos Principle is a single player first person puzzle game that focuses on a philosophical heavy narrative and logic based trial and error puzzles. It combines stellar visuals, a relaxed soundtrack and great writing to create a compelling experience. You’ll get about 36 to 40 hours of content with the base game and DLC expansion combined. Which is a lot more time than I had expected to get. Though that will, of course, vary from player to player depending on how well they can solve these type of puzzles, whether they use guides to get through the game or pursue the bonus stars and hidden secrets. Like all good first person puzzle games, the temptation to use Internet guides can be hard to resist and there are some very good Steam Guides that’ll help the player along. If you enjoy this type of puzzle solving, I implore you to try and figure each puzzle out on your own. It’s a really rewarding experience, at least it was for myself, to solve a puzzle I had been stuck on for a while. However, it’s ultimately your choice.

Puzzle Mechanics
There was never any puzzle I truly disliked or thought “man, that was terribly designed”. Most of the time, it was just my own ineptitude that prevented me from solving it. Though I think star puzzles were just the developers being cruel to us mere mortals. I will admit that I used a guide a couple of times for story and star puzzles when I just couldn’t figure out a particular puzzle. Which led to me finding out that I missing a single step in my logic chain. Cue the expletives. Although there were a couple in Road to Gehenna that I was legitimately stuck on. Overall, I really enjoyed the puzzle design in this game and how unique every puzzle felt like, even though it only had a set amount of mechanics to work with. It always felt like a new challenge that I was gunhoe to tackle head on.

The Talos Principle Story
The Talos Principle is an exploration of freedom, free choice, religion, personal beliefs, the meaning of life, hope, hopelessness, life, death and what has come before. So many different themes are brought up but remain consistent to this central theme that it's trying to explore. It doesn’t force a particular moral. But it does ask the player to consider the themes it presents. It explores how strong your conviction is in your ideals and where those ideals may lead. This combines well with the puzzle and audio design which encourages the player to slow down and consider the puzzles both in the game and in life itself. There’s a subtlety to this game that makes it hard to describe without giving too much away. But I can say that how you respond will affect the narrative a little and the game will remember it.

PC Settings & Video/Audio
TTP is built on the Serious Engine and contains a wealth of PC settings for the player to customize their experience. The performance options include default settings for the CPU/GPU as well as the ability to completely customize them. The GPU settings page here alone scrolls for a long while and I won’t list out every single option. But everything from texture filtering to lighting effects to shadows is all here and it’s an insane amount of choices. I’m pretty sure it’s the biggest list of options I’ve ever seen. Steam workshop support and a benchmark tool are in it as well. Game can be launched in either 32bit or 64bit. Sound options include sliders for master, effects and music volume. It’s extremely well optimized and I had no trouble getting it to run at 1080p 60FPS while running at ultra settings for the CPU and GPU. I didn’t notice much texture pop-in, poorly done textures or other visual glitches (outside of intentional visual glitches) that could ruin one’s experience. Outside of first starting the game and having the game sometimes take a while to load textures. All in all, an impressive amount of options.

All of these puzzles in the base game are handled in three hub worlds and a massive tower. The three hub worlds feature their own unique environments and music. Each environment is absolutely gorgeous to look at. I can’t help but think that the Talos Principle may have been crafted just to show off what the Serious Engine can do when when it’s not about blowing up aliens trying to invade the earth. The soundtrack is a relaxing yet haunting orchestra that fits the visual design of the place you’re visiting. The audio design is further complemented with atmospheric touches to draw the player in.

Final Thoughts
The Talos Principle is one of my favorite puzzle games of all time. The puzzles are very well designed, challenging yet don’t depend on gimmicky mechanics to be hard. The philosophical, religious and social commentary on past and present culture is handled very well to show multiple points of views without being overbearing in any particular way. I think what I find even more impressive for myself is that I didn’t find the 36 hours I played to get boring. I have never enjoyed a premise, game mechanics as a whole or the entire pacing of the game as much as I have for The Talos Principle. During the 36 hours I spent, never once did I want it to simply end and be done with. Each new puzzle felt unique and had a reason to exist beyond simply being iterative design. The music and atmosphere combine to encourage the players to slow down and contemplate the challenge in front of them. What’s even more impressive is that the game mechanics and story compliment each other really well. The visuals are stunning, showcasing Roman, Greek and Egyptian architecture and beautiful worlds to explore. Even at the end of the long journey through TTP, I still want more puzzles to solve, more philosophical discussion to ponder and ideas to challenge. I still want more and yet if this is all that will come from TTP, I am satisfied with the experience I had. It’s so rare to have that kind of feeling about a game. This is one of the few rare gems in gaming that I get to experience and I definitely recommend it.

Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[kingisaaclinksr.com]Road To Gehenna DLC Thoughts

There is truly no way to recommend this game enough. Gives rise to some SERIOUS existential thinking, it's absolutely beautiful to look at and challenging to even long term fans of the puzzle genre. Absolutely the only downside is that the puzzles have only a few mechanics, but even this is overcome by the way in which the level design is put together - what you thought you knew from that puzzle a few levels ago is pretty much the same in this one, but disguised in such a way that its hard to tell you've only recently done pretty much the same thing.

Demo doesn't have any story hooks, but shows the gameplay well - I bought the game based off this alone and I regret not one single penny!

An enthralling experience, filled to the brim with puzzles, secrets, easter eggs and superbly presented storyline. reviewText:
The Talos Principle is a first person puzzler game which has beautiful graphics and wonderfully memorable music. The atmosphere of the game grabs you from the start with its amazing puzzle design and great writing. Provoking narrative, philosophical and metaphysical questions, this game really makes you wonder. Even though it’s very demanding and intense, I couldn’t put the game away when I played it. You constantly have questions that you want answered and it makes you keep thinking, even when after you stop playing.
You play as a sentient artificial intelligence placed within a simulation. From the start you have this narrative voice who explains himself as your god, your creator. You question his logic and you read from other people who both obey and disobey him. As you follow the storyline you read a lot of texts which are written by various people iside the game.

As you are artificial intelligence yourself you also communicate with a help program who asks you tons of questions. You constantly wonder why you are in this simulation, how to get out, what’s outside of the simulation, who’s behind it, there’s always so many questions!

One thing I didn’t like about the game or what I would want to see more of, is that you should question Elohim (your god) and his logic straight to his face. I would like to see more chaos from Elohim and his reaction as you confront him. Much like Glados from portal who tries to kill you when you don't do as she says.
If you’re not the kind of guy who plays for the story, then maybe this game is not for you. I try my best to read everything and follow every single bit when I play. Either way this is one of my favorite and most memorable games I’ve ever played and I would suggest this game even though it’s quite challenging.

reviewText:
I have played the best that 2014 had to offer, and I believe this to be its most important game.

Not only are the puzzles - the gameplay focus of TPP - at least as amazing as Portal's in their design and at times much more difficult, but also the writing rivals the video games' all time bests.
Environmental design is phenomenal, the music soothing.
Extra challenges, secrets and easter eggs galore, and perhaps the best treatment of philosophy in a video game, ever.
Oh, and have I mentioned multiple endings?

If you liked Portal, Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?/Blade Runner, or System Shock - this game is a must for you.
Parallels to Assassin's Creed, and Planescape: Torment can also be found, among others.

Are you a person? Or just a machine? Maybe both?
Play The Talos Principle, and you might just find out.

reviewText:
This has to be one of the best games I have ever played, let me explain why.

Ok, first off, I am a HUGE fan or Portal 1 and 2. So I went into that thinking this might be similar. And in a way, this game is just like portal, but completely turned upside down. The basic layout is the same: You solve interesting puzzles chambers to proceed. The setting however is completely different. Where Portal is about british sarcasm and the interesting storyline between you and GLaDOS (in my opinion), The Talos Principle is a lot more about the existance of life, AI, beautiful scenery and at time exhausting philosophical questions. You can play the game at your own pace, which is something I personally like and you can constantly make your own decisions. And believe me when I say certain choices have a huge impact on the game.

The puzzles themselves are do-able, and occasionally very difficult. I solved them all without help from the internet, just 1 tip from a friend was all I needed to complete all the puzzles. But that doesn't mean they are easy. Some took me incredibly long to solve, but when you do find the solution, it just feels so good! The philosophical stuff they tell you in the game really interested me and gets you thinking. It's some serious stuff, really. After playing for a couple hours straight I was mentally tired of solving all the puzzles and thinking about all these deep issues. You could skip most of it if you really don't care about it, though I don't recommend it because that will remove maybe the biggest part of the game. The narritive (the story) in this game is not the best, but it is very solid and well made. The main focus  of this game are ethical, philosophical questions and the puzzles.

There are also tons of extra things to get, like in Mario, many secret items to find and collect. These can be REALLY hard to collect (I collected only 10% of them I think without help). But if you like more challenges, you can put a lot more time in this game if you want!
Oh one more thing: There are some brilliant (hard to find) Easer Eggs in this game. Try to find them!


All and all, I had the greatest experience playing this game. It was really fun, rewarding and challenging.
If you like challenging puzzles wrapped up in some narrative and a lot of complex philisophical issues, this game is THE perfect game for you! Definately worth it's money! Now I'm off to play the DLC!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After seeing some screenshots of the game, I made the mistake of assuming that this is going to be a by the numbers puzzle game, that wants to borrow some of Portals success. Thinking this, I waited a while before buying it, and now I must say, I regret not picking it up earlier.

I dont think I've ever played a game, that asks the player some of the classic philosophical questions, in such an engaging and creative way as the Talos Principle. What makes us human? What is a soul? What is consciousness? Can a machine achieve it? Those questions have been used plenty of times before, and you may have noticed them in for example movies like the Ghost in the Machine, Bladerunner or Ex Machina. But the Talos Priciple uses them in its own unique way.

There's no denying that Portal and the Talos Priciple have similarities. After all they both revolve around solving puzzles, they have great music scores and voiceacting, and they have pretty similar game mechanics. But thats where I think the similarities end. Where Portal was set in a more confined space, with a playful story and quirky characters, the Talos Priciple is a much more serious take on the genre, with beautiful landscapes to admire and few characters to interact with.

Of course you can just run through the puzzles and ignore the story, but the game wants you to take your time, and ponder on your last action or a message you just heard. And i must admit, that learning more about the world, by finding hidden files or audiologs, felt very rewarding and gave my actions in game more depth than i thought they had to begin with. I dont want to spoil too much about the story and characters, since i feel like this game is best experienced personally, but i highly recommend it

reviewText:
The Talos Principle is a first person puzzle game that allows players to assume the role of a sentient artificial intelligence placed within a simulation of humanity's greatest ruins and linked together through an arcane cathedral. Players are tasked with solving a series of increasingly complex puzzles woven into a metaphysical parable about intelligence and meaning in an inevitably doomed world.
Stunningly beautiful visuals, astonishing and peaceful environments and amazing soundtrack are perfectly combined creating a harmonious and relaxing atmosphere. The story is quite intriguing and mainly given through voice and text archives, fragments of mythology, science, literature, history and personal information such as letters and audio diaries.
This game features multiple endings while also addressing religious subjects, although it's strictly allegorical, metaphorical and plot-driven.
I highly recommend The Talos Principle aswell as Road to Gehenna DLC.

reviewText:
Really great game.  An original approach to puzzle games with a story that really gets you to think.  I thought I had seen every movie/game that blurs the line between AI and consciousness, but this one does it and still manages to keep it fresh.  Amazing.

That said:
Many users have reported numerous game crash issues (myself included), and in many cases this makes the game unplayable.  It's hard to say if it is hardware related, but do not assume that you won't have these issues just because your hardware is powerful.  There is currently a thread about it on the steam community (Game crashes issue - CT needs your assistance").  I would advise anyone considering to buy this game to first check out the posts about these issue

reviewText: Greater than the sum of its parts, The Talos Principle is an excellent addition to the puzzle genre, one that's challenging but always fair, easy to play but always mysterious. The visuals are super clean and colorful. The quantity of puzzles is staggering. Weird as it may seem in a game like this, the story is actually the thing I remember the most. Specifically, the conversations with the Milton Library Assistant are engaging and sometimes unpleasant. You just have to experience it for yourself.\n\nThis is still a puzzle game through and through, and solving these puzzles is what you'll spend 90% of your time doing. Every puzzle mechanic is used with each other in every combination quite nicely, and the game allows for a lot of freedom when it comes to which puzzle you want to attempt next. The only downside to The Talos Principle is the overused puzzle involving tetris pieces. When tackled sporadically they aren't too bad, but they could've used a bit more variety. This is an excellent puzzle game that will challenge you with its puzzles and please you with its graphics and atmosphere. Highly recommend.

reviewText: The Talos Principle is a first-person puzzle game following in the footsteps of Portal.  Overall, I think it's a very well done game with clever puzzles, a great story, and excellent audio.\n\nUltimately, because of the lack of diversity in the settings you'll be solving puzzles in, I don't feel the mechanics alone support the length of this game (assuming you're going for collectiong most of everything). reviewText:
I have played the best that 2014 had to offer, and I believe this to be its most important game.

Not only are the puzzles - the gameplay focus of TPP - at least as amazing as Portal's in their design and at times much more difficult, but also the writing rivals the video games' all time bests.
Environmental design is phenomenal, the music soothing.
Extra challenges, secrets and easter eggs galore, and perhaps the best treatment of philosophy in a video game, ever.
Oh, and have I mentioned multiple endings?

If you liked Portal, Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?/Blade Runner, or System Shock - this game is a must for you.
Parallels to Assassin's Creed, and Planescape: Torment can also be found, among others.

Are you a person? Or just a machine? Maybe both?
Play The Talos Principle, and you might just find out.
